thread.title: Claims ALP candidate 'parachuted' into Central Coast seat
thread.title_full: Claims ALP candidate 'parachuted' into Central Coast seat

author: Sarah Gerathy
title: Claims ALP candidate 'parachuted' into Central Coast seat
text:
Map: Gosford 2250 
The Labor Party has been criticised for "parachuting" Paralympic champion Liesl Tesch as its candidate for the New South Wales seat of Gosford, instead of running a rank-and-file preselection. 
Labor leader Luke Foley is expected to announce this morning that Ms Tesch will contest the Central Coast seat which is being vacated by the party's MP Kathy Smith, who resigned due to ill health. 
But former Labor MP Belinda Neal has lashed out at the Labor Party for the decision, saying it was not adhering to its own democratic principles. 
Ms Tesch, who is a local teacher, had not previously been publicly mentioned as a potential candidate, but the ABC understands the Labor Party has been speaking to the five-time Paralympian for 12 months. 
Ms Neal wanted to run for the seat and yesterday denied claims she had been engaging in branch stacking in an effort to secure it. 
She said Ms Tesch should have to face a preselection contest, not be hand-picked by head office. 
"I think that it's great that Liesl Tesch is prepared to put up her hand, she's obviously someone who comes from within the seat which is a great thing," she said. 
"But I hold the view that we should have a rank-and-file preselection and that the candidate is best chosen by the people who live and work locally." 
Ms Neal accused the Labor Party head office of undemocratic meddling. 
"Sadly what's been happening more and more in the Labor Party is that the people who don't run the party don't respect its rules and traditions," she said. 
"I think it's pretty hard if the party itself doesn't adhere to its own democratic principles. So I think it is a problem." 
Ms Neal said she believed such interventions were turning people away from the party. 
"People don't want their time wasted by game-playing in politics, they want a democratic selection process, they want a candidate they know and trust who lives locally ... not these sort of head office games," Ms Neal said. 
Ms Neal has had a colourful career in politics but is best remembered for the notorious "Iguana-gate" incident, when she was allegedly involved in an altercation with staff at a Central Coast bar . 
The other expected candidate, Anne Charlton, has thrown her support behind the Paralympic gold medallist.
